messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Dear John, Ichi - yes, but the mei in H1715, I have to say no.  The nichi part is not written that way in gyosho or sosho, but the three-stroke radical I
messages.messageBody:
Dear John,
Ichi - yes, but the "mei" in H1715, I have to say no. The nichi part is not written that way in gyosho or sosho, but the three-stroke radical I mentioned before is. The getsu part is also not normally written that way even in sosho, but it's at least possible as a variant. Of course the next two ji are still there to be explained.

Haynes' reference would be to an engraved signature rather than a shumei.

In appraisal documents there is often an "ichi" as in "this item," but I haven't seen it in this sort of shumei. Of course, most if not all of the shumei I've seen on tsuba have been apocryphal, but usually to some obvious "big name."

Sorry I'm not doing better,
Jim


Dear Jim
Further to your helpful suugestions re the lacquer inscription on
the katchushi tsuba, is it possible that the first two kanji are
一 (ichi) and 耼 (mei), as illustrated in Haynes' H 01715.0? Even
the kao bears a (very) remote resemblance to that illustrated.
Regards, John L.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Further to your helpful suugestions re the lacquer inscription on

the kao bears a (very) remote resemblance to that illustrated.
Regards, John L.

messages.msgSnippet: Dear Jim Thank you for the interest that you showed, and the time that you spent on my query.  It is sometimes a frustrating interest; so often there are no
messages.messageBody:
Dear Jim
Thank you for the interest that you showed, and the time that you
spent on my query. It is sometimes a frustrating interest; so often
there are no final answers to our questions.

Regards, John L.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: John, As others have said, today it would probably be attributed to Katchushi.  When I first glanced at the shumei I picked up on the second character as the
messages.messageBody:
John,
As others have said, today it would probably be attributed to Katchushi. When I first glanced at the shumei I picked up on the second character as the "a" 阿 in Shoami and then on the next character as the middle kanji 乙 from Saotome. Of course the rest does not fit either case, although Saotome and Ko-Shoami would be somewhat defensible attributions. The first kanji looks like ichi/kazu 一 and the last ko 小. I can't make sense of it, but feel like I must be missing something obvious. The other character at the left appears to be a kao, although I do not know who it belongs to.

I also spent time on your gold seal when you posted it, but struck out on that one too. I don't have a tensho dictionary so I asked my shodo teacher to look it up, but couldn't conclude on any known tsubako.

They're both bugging me, so if I turn anything up I will post it. Meanwhile, hopefully someone else will take a look and settle it.

Sorry,
Jim




A colleage, and collector, has recently purchased the sukashi tsuba
illustrated in my Photo Album JPL and has asked for my advice
regarding its possible attribution and for a translation of the red
lacquer inscription The figure on the bottom left appears to be a
kao, but I am otherwise at a complete loss. Any help/suggestions re
either of these requests would be much appreciated.

While you are in my Photo Album, I am still seeking some information
on the gold, hira-zogan seal. There has been a complete absence of
replies to my earlier request regarding this.

Grateful thanks and regards, JPL.



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Dr John P Lissenden"
<docliss@j...> wrote:
>
> A colleage, and collector, has recently purchased the sukashi tsuba
> illustrated in my Photo Album JPL and has asked for my advice
> regarding its possible attribution and for a translation of the red
> lacquer inscription The figure on the bottom left appears to be a
> kao, but I am otherwise at a complete loss. Any help/suggestions re
> either of these requests would be much appreciated.
>
> While you are in my Photo Album, I am still seeking some information
> on the gold, hira-zogan seal. There has been a complete absence of
> replies to my earlier request regarding this.
>
> Grateful thanks and regards, JPL. Hello, The gold seal
seems to be a province name, Bishu (Owari not Bizen) perhaps. These
type of scripts make things difficult and I can't figure out the
enamel mei on the tsuba. The style seems to be Katchushi, J.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: John, Without a signature to give me a pointer, it is a daunting prospect to go through the volumes of the Haynes Index and try to match up your gold seal.
messages.messageBody:
John,

Without a signature to give me a pointer, it is a
daunting prospect to go through the volumes of the
Haynes Index and try to match up your gold seal.
Someone more knowledgable may be able to recommend
a more efficient method.

As to the red lacquer attribution, I cannot see it
well enough to read. I will try an opinion later today
after work. Maybe some people will follow suit.

Curran



--- Dr John P Lissenden <docliss@...>

messages.messageBody:
A colleage, and collector, has recently purchased the sukashi tsuba
illustrated in my Photo Album JPL and has asked for my advice
regarding its possible attribution and for a translation of the red
lacquer inscription The figure on the bottom left appears to be a
kao, but I am otherwise at a complete loss. Any help/suggestions re
either of these requests would be much appreciated.

While you are in my Photo Album, I am still seeking some information
on the gold, hira-zogan seal. There has been a complete absence of
replies to my earlier request regarding this.

Grateful thanks and regards, JPL.
